prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 38 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 38 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 38 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. It is always permissible to do research on my personally identifiable sample without my prior permission.  
2. Participants who donate their samples for research should be given special access to the treatments and therapies that result from that research. 
3. Genetic information is different from health information. 
4. Participants should be contacted every time researchers want to use their samples for research.
5. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.  
6. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government. 
7. If someone is a carrier of a genetic disease, they have a responsibility to participate in genetic research.
8. Biobanks are useful even if they only produce more scientific knowledge and not medical advancements.
9. There is no point in consulting the public about ethical issues in science and technology.
10. Aboriginal communities require special consideration concerning healthcare and research.
11. Policy makers should consider the possibility that Canada should not pursue biobanking.
12. There is no risk to the participants who donate to biobanks.
13. Participants should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at anytime. 
14. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies.
15. The community that donates samples for research should receive improved medical services.  
16. I trust researchers to control access to my personal samples.
17. Genetic research will improve our lives.
18. Educating people about health issues (e.g. diet and lifestyle changes) promises greater health effects than investing in biobanks.
19. I should have property rights to my tissues before or after they leave my body.
20. Biobanks need independent review boards to determine who should have access to samples. 
21. Scientists should have access to all unidentified, personal samples for research.
22. The priority for healthcare should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
23. Sampling some people in an ethnocultural community is acceptable only if the whole ethnocultural community has agreed to participate.
24. Everyone should donate samples to a biobank for the benefit of everyone. 
25. I do not care if my donated sample is connected to my name and medical information.
26. All participants should be paid for donating their samples to a biobank. 
27. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health.
28. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
29. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
30. Biobanks will only lead to expensive treatments and high profits. 
31. Researchers should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.  
32. Participants should be active in the set up and oversight of  biobanks. 
33. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for bothers me. 
34. Genetic studies of disability will lead to the discrimination of people living with the same conditions.
35. To me, religious communities need to be consulted about genetic and biobank research. 
36. Profits from biobanking should be returned to the donating community. 
37. Genetic studies of race on enthocultural communities will lead to the discrimination of those same enthocultural communities. 
38. My personal sample should never be anonymized since I should be informed of important research results.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Every use of stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individuals, even if the use does not identify the individual.
2. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals ONLY when the individual is identifiable.
3. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to prevent discrimination (e.g., through insurance, social attitudes) that might result from research on collections of data and biological samples.
4. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), regardless of whether the individual is identifiable.
5. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to ensure benefits to society or the community (e.g., geographical, ethno-cultural) participating in a collection of data and biological samples.
6. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals only when they are identifiable AND approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g. research ethics board) when they are not identifiable.
7. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), ONLY when the individual is identifiable.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Oversight, community benefit, anti-discrimination paramount; consent secondary if anonymized.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 30 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 30 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 30 lines in total.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Animal antibiotical resistance will be the source of the next global pandemic
2. Food waste is an important social issue (e.g. hunger in the world)
3. We should introduce taxes to prevent food waste
4. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
5. It is essential to always have fresh products available to be prepared for any situation (e.g. unexpected guests)
6. Strong regulation of food products will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
7. Extreme weather disasters affect global food availability
8. Farmers should be encouraged to practice ecologically sustainable agriculture, such as permaculture.
9. In Switzerland, packaging waste is a greater environmental issue than food thrown away
10. I am happy to buy fairtrade products, like chocolate or coffee, even if they are of lower quality
11. Food thrown away is natural and biodegradable and thus not an issue for the environment
12. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
13. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
14. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
15. Products that employ products that damage the environment, such as palm oil, should be taxed in a similar fashion to tobacco products
16. Food that is NOT environmentally-sustainable, healthy and fairly-produced should be clearly labelled
17. Switzerland already has some of the toughest regulations about protecting our environment and agriculture
18. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
19. Biodiversity is at risk due to the use of pesticides and monoculture farming
20. The government should ensure that farmers are paid fair prices for their produce to secure higher incomes for those working in agriculture
21. To give subsidies only to farmers who do not use pesticides is an "extreme" approach that would mean falling crop yields and higher food prices
22. I don't care where the product I am buying comes from.
23. Restaurants in schools or retirement homes should only offer vegetarian menus.
24. Food waste is a major environmental issue
25. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
26. If Switzerland implements strong regulations on importing environmentally-sustainable and fairly-produced food, we would either have to step out of our international trade agreements or have to renegotiate most of them
27. The government should apply costum duties on imported products that can be produced in Switzerland (e.g., cheese, honey, apples, beef)
28. Intensive animal farming and monocultural plantation guarantees food supply
29. Subsidies should only be given to farmers that do not use pesticides or antibiotics
30. I am happy to change my nutrition habits, as use leftovers in future meals, if this helps to prevent food waste

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 6 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 6, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 6 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 6 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 6 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Leave the policy settings as they are.
2. Political measures that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable foods (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products).
3. Political measures that focus on less regulation  (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulations)
4. Political measures aimed at investing in research to develop sustainable agricultural techniques or materials.
5. Political measures that include moderate regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning certain pesticides, providing incentives for organic farming).
6. Political measures that include radical regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the import of foods produced using unsustainable methods).

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Support sustainability, research, incentives, moderate regulation; reject inaction/extremes.

1. I don't know what to do. I am very worried and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic set of actions that would truly make a difference.
2. It is difficult to trust scientists' reports on climate change.
3. Planning climate change response measures requires a global approach that considers a wide range of interventions rather than specific individual actions.
4. It is NOT necessary to involve society in deciding which key issues are important for climate change adaptation planning.
5. The urban heat island effect must be tackled with measures such as planting trees.
6. It is important to focus on adaptation measures that take into account the country's economic future.
7. The planning of measures to tackle climate change should focus primarily on extreme weather events such as droughts and floods.
8. Climate change is natural; there is no need to worry.

10. I'm not going to do anything about climate change because it's not an important issue.
11. It is important to support vulnerable groups (the elderly, children, people with disabilities, low-income individuals) as they have fewer resources to deal with the impacts of climate change.
12. There is not enough information to conclusively say that climate change is real.
13. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illnesses and deaths caused by high temperatures.
14. The melting of Alpine glaciers is not a real problem for our daily lives.
15. Doing something to reduce emissions seems a bit hopeless to me, but I just want to feel like I'm doing my best.
16. Climate change is primarily caused by human activity.
17. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to contribute to an effective global solution.
18. Society should be included in the discussion on climate change adaptation.
19. Some countries or regions of the world will be more affected by climate change than others, but this is not our top priority.
20. Authorities have the resources they need to effectively adapt to climate change.
21. It is difficult to trust what the media report about climate change.
22. I believe that the impact we can achieve as individuals in Switzerland is so small that our actions are useless.
23. It is difficult to trust government reports on climate change.
24. We need to take into account the negative effects of climate change on local businesses.
25. Even if Switzerland were to reduce all its CO₂ emissions, global warming would continue.
26. It is necessary to have strong on-the-ground disaster response capabilities to deal with extreme weather conditions.
27. Authorities should receive additional funding to strengthen measures against emergencies and weather-related disasters such as floods.
28. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than protecting ecosystems.
29. It is certain to say that climate change exists.
30. Rising insurance costs are a serious problem related to climate change.
31. It is important to prepare for the migration of people displaced by the effects of climate change.
32. Health systems must prepare for both the physical health impacts of climate change (e.g., heat stroke) and the mental health impacts (e.g., farmers losing their crops).

## [Considerations]:
1. Reducing the risk of vessel collision on the Swan River should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge
2. The safety of the bridge is more important than its appearance.
3. River craft deserve better traffic conditions on the Swan River.
4. This magnificent timber bridge is a rare and beautiful sight in today's world, it should be preserved. 
5. Any changes to the bridge should give right consideration to the environment.bridge
6. We just got traffic calming in Town Centre after 25 years effort. I don't want bridge to be build bigger, better faster to reverse the gains of the last 25 years.
7. Providing a better pedestrian and cycle traffic should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge.
8. The main concern is to have a bridge that underpins the economic activities in the region.
9. It is most important that the solution is a long term one.
10. The problem is not the vulnerable structure of the bridge but excessive traffic, which should be reduced.
11. Alterations will lead to nothing but the uglification of the bridge.
12. Altering or replacing the existing Fremantle Bridge means diminishing Fremantle.
13. Tax payers money should be spent on services that are more essential than upgrading the bridge.
14. The bridge is certainly an attractive entry statement to Fremantle and without doubt far more important than trucks.
15. The function of the Fremantle Bridge as a transport gateway is more important than its heritage.
16. Whatever works are undertaken, the heritage value of the old bridge will be affected.
17. The most important thing is that access to Fremantle from its north is maintained in the most undisturbed manner as possible. 
18. We should definitely preserve the heritage value of the bridge, but only if it is financially viable.
19. Replacing timber elements with steel components would destroy the authentic appearance of the bridge.
20. The existing bridge is too low; archways too narrow and do not line up with the railway bridge making navigation dangerous. 
21. The most important issue for cyclists is safety, which means they need access across the bridge which has a good surface.
22. When deciding about the future of the bridge, indigenous concerns should be given adequate consideration. 
23. Indigenous people would want to minimize impact on the Swan River, a registered site, that is of importance and significance to them.
24. We shouldn't stick to the past when deciding about the future of the bridge, we should be open for modern design options.
25. There are no specific economic benefits for the Fremantle from the bridge.
26. The critical infrastructure of the bridge raises serious safety concerns. 
27. The Fremantle Bridge is irreplaceable. It is a strong, enduring part of our history.
28. It is worth spending money to retain the iconic status of the bridge.
29. The old bridge will never be able to handle vehicles, bike and pedestrians at the same time.
30. The cost of maintaining the old timber structure is too high.
31. Safe and efficient movement of all road and river users across and under the bridge should the main considerations
32. The old bridge provides a scenic entrance to Fremantle that attracts tourists.
33. The Fremantle Traffic Bridge is the most iconic landmark and the main tourist attraction in Fremantle. 
34. The bridge has stood the test of time for the past 67 years; there's no need for major changes to it.
35. As long as there is a bridge that I can cross, I don't care about its structure.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 20 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
2. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
3. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
4. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
5. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
6. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
7. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
8. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
9. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
10. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
11. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
12. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
13. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
14. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
15. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
16. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
17. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
18. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
19. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
20. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. There are too many mental health services in Switzerland, and they should be reduced.
2. There should be more integrated mental health clinics that provide a range of services, such as sports or artistic activities in addition to therapy and medication
3. There are enough mental health services in Switzerland, and funding should remain as it is.
4. Private mental health clinics should receive more government funding to allow more people to access them.
5. There should be more public awareness campaigns that empower people to seek mental health support and destigmatize help-seeking behaviors.
6. Initiatives focused on improving the socioeconomic conditions of disadvantaged people should be implemented to address mental health disparities.
7. There are not enough mental health services in Switzerland, so their funding should be increased.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Boost funding & access, tackle social causes, raise awareness, reject cuts.

42. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
43. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
44. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
45. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
46. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
47. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
48. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
49. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
2. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
3. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
4. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
5. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
6. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
7. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.

- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Strong privacy, regulation, public benefit, consent, and equity are key priorities.

1. I don't know if improving the Bloomfield Track would lead to a rapid acceleration of development in the area to the detriment of the environment.

19. In deciding on what to do with the Bloomfield Track I don't know whether it's more important to meet the needs of the community or the environment.
20. I think that both short and long term perspectives are needed in deciding what should be done with the Bloomfield Track, but I don't know which one is more important.

## [Considerations]:
1. A lot of people may be politically ignorant, but they believe what they see and hear on television, and that makes them vote the way they do. They have been brainwashed by the clever advertising people.
2. There is a lot of consultation by govt – but who is listening?  And what power do they have to make changes?
3. I don't want to be in a place where only a minority's viewpoint gets the right to say what's going to happen.
4. We are a democratic country.
5. Free markets work because individual people, cooperating peacefully and voluntarily through markets, can achieve much that politicians and bureaucrats cannot achieve using compulsion and direction.
6. The only time we are all equal is when we vote in the ballot box.
7. The political system is remote and closed and the connection with elected representatives is difficult, they are often faceless.
8. I suppose we do have an upper class and a lower class.
9. I don't think there's anything wrong with people voting for their self-interest.
10. There's a dollar democracy that runs through our supposed democracy.
11. If Australia is to recover from the horrible mess we are in at present, we will need leaders of high principles, who will govern with honesty, justice, and righteousness, fearlessly putting into practice the principles of the Bible.
12. Democracy means we, the people, are responsible for what government does, or fails to do.
13. Sometimes I get a bit worried that there's a lot of small minority groups that tend to get a lot of the say
14. The last thing we need is a Canberra 'Big Brother' telling us what we should read and hear.
15. Not voting is a form of expression. It's a way of telling parties that no one is offering policies that appeal to you.
16. We should not be afraid of disagreement. Indeed, an important feature of a liberal democracy is respect for conflicting ideas; difference is part of the human condition. 
17. We suffer a Parliamentary Democracy and an archaic and conflict oriented, "two party system" where one of two main parties will manipulate us for the next few years. 
18. In the Senate there should be elected representatives who are not from the major parties but from smaller interest groups.
19. I'm always cynical about government processes.
20. If you want your vote to count for anything, then you need to not vote in ignorance, you need to know something about what you're being offered.
21. The people we elect are loyal not to we dumb bunnies who elected them, but the agenda and dogma of their party. 
22. We live in a great democracy.
23. Democracy is a term which has lost much of its original meaning.
24. We should strengthen protections of the free press in order to facilitate a more open and publicly accountable government. 
25. The party system is the main obstruction to accountable politics.
26. Our government is attempting to mould our society to the needs of a profit-oriented market
27. I don't think we have a lot of input into legislation and a lot of things that are important.
28. Governments can talk a great game about 'democracy'. They fall down, in practice, because they cannot accept any sharing of the power to influence decisions with those who might have different motives and ideas.
29. The true believers are about decency in life, about a capacity to debate the issues and to receive different views.
30. You don't have to wait three years to say 'I'm not happy with the job you did.' You can apply pressure, and enough people writing to the local member can turn the situation around.
31. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.
32. There is no real difference in ideological terms between the major parties and preference distributions are problematic.
33. Democracy means that all policy is exposed to open discussion and debate in a public political space of all citizens before being put to a transparent, accountable vote.

21. Our community and nation should invoke a spirit that you are important, that you do have a way of influencing things.
22. Low female participation rates compound the domination of the public realm by males.
23. I don't think we have a lot of input into legislation and a lot of things that are important.
24. I suppose we do have an upper class and a lower class.
25. We should strengthen protections of the free press in order to facilitate a more open and publicly accountable government. 
26. The party system is the main obstruction to accountable politics.
27. If Australia is to recover from the horrible mess we are in at present, we will need leaders of high principles, who will govern with honesty, justice, and righteousness, fearlessly putting into practice the principles of the Bible.
28. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.
29. Our political system's strength is that it can change to meet changing circumstances.
30. The only time we are all equal is when we vote in the ballot box.
31. I don't think there's anything wrong with people voting for their self-interest.
32. Until women are equally represented in Australian parliaments, we will not have a genuine representative democracy.
33. I don't want to be in a place where only a minority's viewpoint gets the right to say what's going to happen.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
2. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
3. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
4. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
5. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
6. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
7. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
8. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
9. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
10. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
11. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
12. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
13. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
14. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
15. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
16. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
17. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
18. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
19. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
20. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
21. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
22. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
23. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
24. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
25. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
26. Forest health means jobs.
27. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
28. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
29. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
30. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
31. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
32. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
33. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
34. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
35. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
36. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
37. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
38. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
39. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
40. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
41. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
42. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
43. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
44. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
45. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires.

- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].

## [Example output]:

2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
2. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
3. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
4. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
5. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
6. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
7. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
8. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
9. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
10. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
11. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
12. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
13. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
14. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
15. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
16. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
17. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
18. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
19. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
20. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
21. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
22. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
23. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
24. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
25. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
26. Forest health means jobs.
27. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
28. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
29. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
30. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
31. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
32. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
33. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
34. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
35. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
36. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
37. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
38. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
39. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
40. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
41. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
42. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
43. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
44. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
45. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
2. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
3. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
4. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
5. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
6. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
7. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
8. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
9. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
10. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
11. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
12. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
13. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
14. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
15. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
16. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
17. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
18. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
19. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
20. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
21. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
22. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
23. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
24. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
25. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
26. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
27. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
28. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
29. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
30. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
31. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
32. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
33. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
34. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
35. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
36. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
37. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
38. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
39. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
40. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
41. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
42. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
43. Forest health means jobs.
44. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
45. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.

## [Considerations]:
1. I am happy to change my nutrition habits, as use leftovers in future meals, if this helps to prevent food waste
2. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
3. Food waste is a major environmental issue
4. Intensive animal farming and monocultural plantation guarantees food supply
5. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
6. Switzerland already has some of the toughest regulations about protecting our environment and agriculture
7. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
8. Animal antibiotical resistance will be the source of the next global pandemic
9. Food waste is an important social issue (e.g. hunger in the world)
10. Strong regulation of food products will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
11. Farmers should be encouraged to practice ecologically sustainable agriculture, such as permaculture.
12. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
13. The government should ensure that farmers are paid fair prices for their produce to secure higher incomes for those working in agriculture
14. Food thrown away is natural and biodegradable and thus not an issue for the environment
15. It is essential to always have fresh products available to be prepared for any situation (e.g. unexpected guests)
16. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
17. Food that is NOT environmentally-sustainable, healthy and fairly-produced should be clearly labelled
18. I am happy to buy fairtrade products, like chocolate or coffee, even if they are of lower quality
19. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
20. The government should apply costum duties on imported products that can be produced in Switzerland (e.g., cheese, honey, apples, beef)
21. We should introduce taxes to prevent food waste
22. I don't care where the product I am buying comes from.
23. If Switzerland implements strong regulations on importing environmentally-sustainable and fairly-produced food, we would either have to step out of our international trade agreements or have to renegotiate most of them
24. Biodiversity is at risk due to the use of pesticides and monoculture farming
25. To give subsidies only to farmers who do not use pesticides is an "extreme" approach that would mean falling crop yields and higher food prices
26. In Switzerland, packaging waste is a greater environmental issue than food thrown away
27. Extreme weather disasters affect global food availability
28. Restaurants in schools or retirement homes should only offer vegetarian menus.
29. Products that employ products that damage the environment, such as palm oil, should be taxed in a similar fashion to tobacco products
30. Subsidies should only be given to farmers that do not use pesticides or antibiotics

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 6 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 6, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 6 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 6 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 6 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Leave the policy settings as they are.
2. Political measures that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable foods (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products).
3. Political measures that include radical regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the import of foods produced using unsustainable methods).
4. Political measures aimed at investing in research to develop sustainable agricultural techniques or materials.
5. Political measures that include moderate regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning certain pesticides, providing incentives for organic farming).
6. Political measures that focus on less regulation  (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulations)

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Favor sustainability, fair trade, less waste via incentives & balanced regulation.

4. Political measures that focus on less regulation  (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulations)
5. Political measures aimed at investing in research to develop sustainable agricultural techniques or materials.
6. Political measures that include moderate regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning certain pesticides, providing incentives for organic farming).

- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Support sustainable food via incentives, research, moderate rules; avoid extremes.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
2. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
3. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
4. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
5. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
6. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
7. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
8. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
9. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
10. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
11. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
12. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
13. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
14. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
15. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
16. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
17. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
18. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
19. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
20. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
21. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
22. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
23. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
24. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
25.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
26. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
27. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
28. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
29. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
30. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
31. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
32. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
33. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
34. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
35. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
36. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
37. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
38. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
39. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
40. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
41. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
42. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
43. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
44. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
45. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 9 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 9, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 9 the option you support the least.

2. Solar Energy
3. Nuclear Energy
4. Natural Gas
5. Hydroelectric
6. Wind
7. Coal
8. Biomass
9. Coal with CO2 Burial

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize conservation, renewables, nuclear; phase out coal; wary of CCS/biomass.

29. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
30. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
31. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
32. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
33.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
34. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
35. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
36. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
37. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
38. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
39. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
40. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
41. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
42. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
43. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
44. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
45. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.

5. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
6. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
7. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
8. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
9. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.

11.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
12. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
13. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
14. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
15. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
16. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
17. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
18. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.

20. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.

22. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
23. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
24. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
25. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
26. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
27. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
28. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
29. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
30. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
31. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
32. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
33. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
34. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
35. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
36. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
37. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
38. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
39. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
40. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
41. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
42. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
43. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
44. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.

30. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
31. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
32. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
33. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
34. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
35. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
36. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
37. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
38. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
39. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
40. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
41. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
42. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
43. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
44. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
45. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.

3. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
4. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.

6. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.

8. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.

10. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
11. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
12. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
13. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
14. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
15. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
16. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
17. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
18. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
19. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
20. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
21. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
22. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
23. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
24. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
25. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
26. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
27. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
28. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
29. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
30. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
31. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
32. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
33. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
34. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
35. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
36. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
37. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
38. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
39. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
40. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
41.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
42. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
43. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
44. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
45. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
