## [Considerations]:
1. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
2. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
3. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
4. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
5. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
6. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
7. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
8. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
9. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
10. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
11. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
12. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
13. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
14. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
15. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
16. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
17. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
18. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
19. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
20. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
21. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
22. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
23. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
24. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
25. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
26. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
27. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
28. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
29. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
30. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
31. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
32. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
33. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
34. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
35. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
36. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
37. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
38. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
39. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
40. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
41. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
42. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
43. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
44.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
45. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.

## [Considerations]:
1. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
2. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
3. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
4. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
5. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
6. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
7. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
8. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
9. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
10. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
11. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
12. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
13. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
14. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
15. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
16. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
17. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
18. Genetic research will improve our lives.
19. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
20. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
21. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
22. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
23. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
24. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
25. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
26. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
27. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
28. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
29. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
30. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
31. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
32. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
33. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
34. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
35. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
36. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
37. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
38. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
39. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
40. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
41. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
42. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
43. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
44. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
45. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
46. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
47. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
48. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
49. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.

- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

## [Policies]:
1. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
2. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
3. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
4. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
5. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
6. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
7. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize strong oversight, privacy, public benefit; wary of minimal regulation & pure commerce.

response: Prioritize strong regulation, privacy, and community benefit in biobanking.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
2. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
3. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.
4. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
5. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
6. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
7. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
8. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
9. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
10. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
11. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
12. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
13. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
14. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
15. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
16. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
17. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
18. Genome editing is really cool science.
19. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
20. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
21. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
22. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
23. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
24. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
25. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
26. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
27. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
28. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
29. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
30. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
31. I would consider using genome editing for my children to give them an advantage in life, so long as it's safe.
32. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
33. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
34. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
35. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
36. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
37. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
38. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
39. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
40. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
41. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
42. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
43. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
44. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
45. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 8 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 8, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 8 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 8 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 8 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing for clinical treatments, and mitochondrial donation.
2. Prohibit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation.
3. Prohibit all forms of human genome editing for now, except for research purposes.
4. Permit non-heritable and heritable human genome editing (including mitochondrial donation), but only for clinical purposes, and if there is strong oversight, regular community input and (re)approval.
5. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit.
6. Permit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit
7.  Permit both heritable and non-heritable uses of genome editing for any purpose with minimal restrictions to ensure safety and compliance with ethical standards.
8.  Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Favor non-heritable medical editing if safe/equitable; oppose heritable/enhancement uses.

25. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.

28. Genome editing is really cool science.
29. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
30. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
31. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
32. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
33. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
34. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
35. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
36. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
37. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
38. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
39. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.

2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
2. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
3. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
4. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.
5. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
6. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
7. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
8. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
9. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
10. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
11. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
12. I would consider using genome editing for my children to give them an advantage in life, so long as it's safe.
13. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
14. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
15. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
16. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
17. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
18. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
19. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
20. Genome editing is really cool science.
21. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
22. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
23. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
24. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
25. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
26. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
27. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
28. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
29. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
30. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
31. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
32. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
33. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
34. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
35. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
36. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
37. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
38. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
39. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
40. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
41. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
42. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
43. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
44. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
45. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 36 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 36 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
2. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
3. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
4. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
5. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
6. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
7. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
8. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
9. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
10. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
11. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
12. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
13. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
14. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
15. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
16. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
17. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
18. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
19. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
20. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
21. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
22. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
23. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
24. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
25. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
26. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
27. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
28. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
29. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
30. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
31. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
32. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
33. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
34. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
35. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
36. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 4 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 4, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 4 the option you support the least.

4. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
5. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
6. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
7. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
8. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
9. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
10. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
11. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
12. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
13. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
14. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
15. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
16. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
17. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
18. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
19. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
20. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
21. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
22. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
23. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
24. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
25. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
26. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
27. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
28. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
29. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
30. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
31. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
32. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
33. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
34. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
35. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
36. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"

## [Considerations]:
1. Limiting the influence of private insurance companies in the Swiss healthcare system would help avoid higher costs without improving the quality of care.
2. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
3. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
4. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
5. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
6. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
7. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.
8. Government control of drug prices would prevent pharmaceutical companies from charging excessive prices.
9. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.
10. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.
11. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.
12. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
13. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
14. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
15. Better coordination between primary care, hospitals, and specialists is essential for the effective treatment of chronic diseases.
16. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
17. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
18. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
19. Reducing the scope of mandatory health insurance coverage could help lower overall healthcare costs.
20. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
21. A more centralized healthcare system, such as national hospital planning, would better organize and improve efficiency in healthcare.
22. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
23. Income-based health insurance contributions would make insurance fairer for low-income individuals.
24. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.

2. More government control over pricing and greater financial support (e.g., individual premium subsidies) would help those in need.
3. Less government regulation and more private competition would make healthcare more efficient and cost-effective.

5. Fixing financial inefficiencies in the healthcare system could save a lot of money without major changes to the system.
6. Encouraging more personal responsibility by abolishing mandatory health insurance and increasing out-of-pocket payments.

5. More government control over pricing and greater financial support (e.g., individual premium subsidies) would help those in need.
6. Fixing financial inefficiencies in the healthcare system could save a lot of money without major changes to the system.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Favor universal access via efficiency, income-based costs, and prevention.

12. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
13. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.

18. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
19. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.
20. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
21. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
22. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 43 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 43 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 43 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
2. Agricultural subsidies should promote sustainable, pesticide and antibiotic-free production.
3. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
4. There's not much point in me doing anything to make agriculture more sustainable. No-one else is going to.
5. “Actions on the food system in Switzerland will lead to increased imports and shift of the pollution abroad”
6. The main focus of planning for adaptation should be to prepare the food system for extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding. 
7. The Swiss food system is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
8. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
9. Sustainable agriculture increases prices and harms consumer freedom. The production should be adapted to what people demand.
10. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
11. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
12. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by malnutrition and famine.
13. The Swiss food system depends on imports from other countries, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
14. Agriculture is already very sustainable. Swiss farmers are on the right track
15. There is not enough information to definitively establish if the link between the agri-food system and climate change is real.
16. We should develop short distribution channels and support local production instead of supporting big agrifood corporations
17. Planning for food system adaptation needs a holistic approach, considering a whole range of issues, instead of focussing on individual issues. 
18. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for food system changes.
19. I'm not going to do anything to address the impacts of the agri-food system because it is not a major issue.
20. We need actions to protect inhabitants and the biodiversity from harmful pesticide.
21. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
22. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.
23. The community should be involved in discussions about food system adaptation.
24. Some communities are more affected than others by the global agri-food system, but this is not a priority issue.
25. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
26. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
27. The negative effects of the climate change on local commerce should be taken into account.
28. Strong regulation of food production will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
29. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
30. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
31. As long as we use animals in agriculture, it cannot be sustainable
32. “Food accessibility (price) and security (availability) is NOT COMPATIBLE with a sustainable food system”
33. It is important to support smal land local farming as they have the fewest resources to deal with impacts of climate change. 
34. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
35. “Intensive food production can go along with the protection of the environment and health”
36. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by intensive use of pesticides/antibiotics
37. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
38. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases of its food system it won't make a difference.
39. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
40. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
41. We need to deal with the water pollution issue through measures such as reducing fertilizer and pesticide use.
42. Products that use environmentally harmful ingredients, such as palm oil, should be taxed in the same way as tobacco products.
43. “Farmers already suffer enough from strict rules and paperwork. Family farmers should have more liberties”

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Policies that involve a radical sustainable food regulation (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the importation of food related product that employ non-sustanable approaches, exclusively incentivising organic agriculture)
2. Preparing for climate risk for food production through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.
3. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
4. Policies that involve a moderate sustainable regulations (e.g., banning certain types of pesticides, incentivising organic agriculture)
5. Leave the policy settings as they are.
6. Policies that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable food (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products)
7. Policies that emphasise fewer regulations (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulation)

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Support strong sustainable food regulation, localism, and climate action.

- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
2. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
3. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
4. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
5. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
6. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
7. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
8. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
9. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
10. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
11. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
12. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
13. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
14. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 36 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 36 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. This magnificent timber bridge is a rare and beautiful sight in today's world, it should be preserved. 
2. The bridge has stood the test of time for the past 67 years; there's no need for major changes to it.
3. It is worth spending money to retain the iconic status of the bridge.
4. Alterations will lead to nothing but the uglification of the bridge.
5. The main concern is to have a bridge that underpins the economic activities in the region.
6. The existing bridge is too low; archways too narrow and do not line up with the railway bridge making navigation dangerous. 
7. The function of the Fremantle Bridge as a transport gateway is more important than its heritage.
8. We should definitely preserve the heritage value of the bridge, but only if it is financially viable.
9. River craft deserve better traffic conditions on the Swan River.
10. There are no specific economic benefits for the Fremantle from the bridge.
11. The most important issue for cyclists is safety, which means they need access across the bridge which has a good surface.
12. The old bridge provides a scenic entrance to Fremantle that attracts tourists.
13. It is most important that the solution is a long term one.
14. The cost of maintaining the old timber structure is too high.
15. Safe and efficient movement of all road and river users across and under the bridge should the main considerations
16. The old bridge will never be able to handle vehicles, bike and pedestrians at the same time.
17. Tax payers money should be spent on services that are more essential than upgrading the bridge.
18. When deciding about the future of the bridge, indigenous concerns should be given adequate consideration. 
19. Altering or replacing the existing Fremantle Bridge means diminishing Fremantle.
20. The problem is not the vulnerable structure of the bridge but excessive traffic, which should be reduced.
21. As long as there is a bridge that I can cross, I don't care about its structure.
22. The Fremantle Bridge is irreplaceable. It is a strong, enduring part of our history.
23. Providing a better pedestrian and cycle traffic should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge.
24. The Fremantle Traffic Bridge is the most iconic landmark and the main tourist attraction in Fremantle. 
25. Whatever works are undertaken, the heritage value of the old bridge will be affected.
26. Indigenous people would want to minimize impact on the Swan River, a registered site, that is of importance and significance to them.
27. We shouldn't stick to the past when deciding about the future of the bridge, we should be open for modern design options.
28. Since the traffic bridge has important heritage significance, the only grounds for its removal should be on the grounds of serious safety issues and verified by heritage engineers.
29. Replacing timber elements with steel components would destroy the authentic appearance of the bridge.
30. Reducing the risk of vessel collision on the Swan River should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge
31. The safety of the bridge is more important than its appearance.
32. The bridge is certainly an attractive entry statement to Fremantle and without doubt far more important than trucks.
33. The most important thing is that access to Fremantle from its north is maintained in the most undisturbed manner as possible. 
34. Any changes to the bridge should give right consideration to the environment.bridge
35. The critical infrastructure of the bridge raises serious safety concerns. 
36. We just got traffic calming in Town Centre after 25 years effort. I don't want bridge to be build bigger, better faster to reverse the gains of the last 25 years.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 6 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 6, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 6 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 6 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 6 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Construct a new standard bridge next to the current bridge, leaving a section of the existing bridge as a heritage and recreation site
2. Construct a new bridge that is a major entry statements for Fremantle, leaving a section of the existing bridge as a heritage recreation site
3. Construct a new two lane standard bridge and retain the existing bridge as a 2 lane bridge with improved pedestrian/cyclist facilities
4. Retain existing bridge, but replace the navigation spans and deteriorated components
5. Construct a new standard bridge and retain the existing bridge as a pedestrian/cyclist facility
6. Retain existing bridge, but replace the navigation spans and deteriorated components and incorporate bridge widening

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.

response: Safety, function, long-term viability, indigenous/heritage respect guided choices.

7. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
8. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
9. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
10. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
11. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
12. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
13. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
14. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
15. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
16. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
17. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
18. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
19. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
20. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
21. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
22. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
23. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
24. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
25. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
26. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
27. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
28. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
29. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
30. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
31. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
32. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
33. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
34. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
35. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
36. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
